G.L. c. 186, \u0016714.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, 714, every residential lease in Massachusetts includes an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment, guaranteeing that the tenant shall not be interfered with in her peaceful use and enjoyment of the premises by the acts or omissions of the landlord.

G.L. c. 218, \u0016719.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper in the Worcester District Court pursuant to G.L. c. 218, 719, as this action concerns a residential tenancy located within Worcester County and the amount in controversy does not exceed $50,000.

G.L. c. 223, \u001672.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court under G.L. c. 223, 72 because the property at issue is located in Worcester, Massachusetts, and Defendant conducts business as a landlord there.

*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: Massachusetts law provides that a landlords inaction leading to persistent unsanitary conditions or infestations interfering with the tenants comfort and safety amounts to a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The court squarely interprets G.L. c. 186, § 14’s “quiet enjoyment” language in light of the common-law covenant and holds that a landlord’s failure to maintain sanitary, watertight conditions—here, repeated sewage flooding—constitutes interference with quiet enjoyment when it impairs the character and value of the premises. The opinion expressly ties liability under § 14 to the landlord’s violation of its duty to maintain sanitary conditions and recognizes that unsanitary conditions harm tenants’ comfort and safety regardless of intent, thereby supporting the proposition that such inaction amounts to a breach of quiet enjoyment under Massachusetts law.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’… When the Legislature chose the words ‘quiet enjoyment’… it must have intended to incorporate these cases into the statute.… [G]em is liable to Solomon under G. L. c. 186, § 14 because it violated its underlying duty to maintain sanitary conditions in her apartment, and thereby permitted repeated flooding to occur that interfered with her quiet enjoyment of her apartment.”

*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (199.proposition: Massachusetts law provides that a landlords inaction leading to persistent unsanitary conditions or infestations interfering with the tenants comfort and safety amounts to a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (199.support_reasoning: The case is not about unsanitary conditions or infestations, but it articulates the governing standard for when a landlord’s inaction violates the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14. The court explains that negligent failure to repair known defects (after notice) that foreseeably interfere with the tenant’s use—including conditions like leaks or failure to maintain habitability—constitutes a breach. By approving prior cases finding § 14 violations where landlords failed to remedy known defects affecting habitability, the opinion indirectly supports the broader proposition that persistent uncorrected unsanitary or infestation conditions interfering with comfort and safety can amount to a breach.
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (199.relevant_excerpt: We noted that a landlord’s failure ‘to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.’ See Cruz, supra at 789, citing Simon v. Solomon, supra at 103 (failure to control floods in tenant’s apartment); Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761 (1979) (failure to repair leaky roof); Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959, 960 (1985) (failure to bring apartment into habitable condition and keep it so).

*Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855 (199.proposition: Massachusetts law provides that a landlords inaction leading to persistent unsanitary conditions or infestations interfering with the tenants comfort and safety amounts to a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
*Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855 (199.support_reasoning: The opinion describes extremely unsanitary conditions and infestations and affirms tenant recovery on multiple theories, but the court does not analyze or even discuss the covenant of quiet enjoyment claim under G.L. c. 186, § 14. The holding focuses on c. 93A, intentional infliction of emotional distress, and warranty of habitability damages, without articulating any rule that a landlord’s inaction causing persistent unsanitary conditions or infestations constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. Thus, it does not provide authority for the specific legal proposition stated.
*Haddad v. Gonzalez*, 410 Mass. 855 (199.relevant_excerpt: After his view, the judge made express findings. Among other defects, the judge found that: (1) there was no functioning heating system; ... (8) the apartment was infested with cockroaches and rodents.... The judge ordered Haddad to repair most of the defects by August 22, 1983. He also ordered Haddad to install a heating system by September 15, 1983, and to have the apartment treated by a professional exterminator. ... Based on the findings, as summarized above, the judge found in favor of Gonzalez on each of her counterclaims. To avoid awarding cumulative damages, however, the judge dismissed all but the retaliation and c. 93A counterclaims.

*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.proposition: Massachusetts law provides that a landlords inaction leading to persistent unsanitary conditions or infestations interfering with the tenants comfort and safety amounts to a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.support_reasoning: The case does hold that a landlord’s failure to act, where the landlord created and could control objectionable conditions, can breach the covenant of quiet enjoyment, even without an intent to do so. However, Blackett involves noise and disturbance from a bar, not unsanitary conditions or infestations, and the opinion never discusses sanitation, pests, or similar conditions. Thus, while it supports a broader principle of landlord liability for inaction causing substantial interference, it does not specifically support the proposition as framed about unsanitary conditions or infestations.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.relevant_excerpt: “There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done… Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent…”

*Youghal, LLC v. Entwistle*, 484 Mass. 1.proposition: Massachusetts law provides that a landlords inaction leading to persistent unsanitary conditions or infestations interfering with the tenants comfort and safety amounts to a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.

*Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 M.proposition: Defendants failure also violates the implied warranty of habitability recognized in *Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 Mass. 184 (1973), and constitutes a dangerous or unsanitary condition contrary to the Massachusetts State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.550 and 410.600, which require landlords to maintain the premises free of rodent infestation.
*Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 M.support_reasoning: The concurrence squarely recognizes that renting a dwelling unit carries an implied obligation, derived from the State Sanitary Code and related laws, to provide premises that meet minimum standards of fitness for human habitation, and that violations of those legal standards (including unsanitary or dangerous conditions) can limit the landlord’s rent recovery. Although this is a concurring/dissenting opinion and it does not mention rodents or 105 C.M.R. 410.550/410.600 specifically, it supports the general proposition that a landlord’s failure to maintain code-compliant, sanitary conditions breaches an implied habitability obligation. Thus it is reasonably supportive authority for tying sanitary code violations (such as rodent infestation) to breach of an implied warranty of habitability, but only at a general level.
*Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 M.relevant_excerpt: “The Code…fixes minimum standards of fitness of structures for human habitation… It expressly provides that ‘[n]o person shall … let to another for occupancy any dwelling… which does not comply’ with its provisions… As the first step in the removal of the roadblock discussed above I would…hold instead (a) that the various statutes, ordinances, by-laws, rules, regulations and codes prescribing minimum standards for dwelling units impose on the landlord, for the benefit of his tenants, an obligation to comply with those minimum standards….”

Massachusetts State Sanitary Code, 105 C.raw_text: Massachusetts State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.550 and 410.600
Massachusetts State Sanitary Code, 105 C.proposition: Defendants failure also violates the implied warranty of habitability recognized in *Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 Mass. 184 (1973), and constitutes a dangerous or unsanitary condition contrary to the Massachusetts State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.550 and 410.600, which require landlords to maintain the premises free of rodent infestation.

*Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman*, 417 Mass. 7.proposition: Defendants conduct constitutes a violation of G.L. c. 186, 714, entitling Plaintiff to recover actual and consequential damages, or three months rent, whichever is greater, plus reasonable attorneys fees and court costs.
*Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman*, 417 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns breach of the implied warranty of habitability, the measure of those damages in a Section 8 tenancy, and related G.L. c. 93A and retaliation claims. Although G.L. c. 186, § 14 is mentioned as the statutory basis for a quiet enjoyment claim, the court expressly notes that no § 14 damages were awarded to avoid duplication, and there is no discussion of the statutory remedies (actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, plus fees and costs) or a holding that the defendant’s conduct constituted a § 14 violation. Thus, the case does not provide authority for the proposition about entitlement to the specific § 14 remedies described.
*Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman*, 417 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “Wideman filed counterclaims alleging (1) breach of the implied warranty of habitability; (2) breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, see G. L. c. 186, § 14 (1992 ed.); (3) retaliation, see G. L. c. 186, § 18 (1992 ed.); and (4) violations of G. L. c. 93A (1992 ed.). … Although the judge found a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, he awarded no damages on this claim to avoid what would have been a duplicative award. See Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 107-111 (1982).”

*Winchester v. O\u0019Brien*, 266 Mass..proposition: Defendants conduct constitutes a violation of G.L. c. 186, 714, entitling Plaintiff to recover actual and consequential damages, or three months rent, whichever is greater, plus reasonable attorneys fees and court costs.
*Winchester v. O\u0019Brien*, 266 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion predates and does not interpret G.L. c. 186, §14, nor does it mention any statutory scheme for enhanced statutory damages, treble rent, attorney’s fees, or costs under that statute. Instead, it recognizes common-law remedies (tort and equitable relief) for landlord interference with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment and awards actual damages based on nuisance/trespass-type theories. Therefore, it cannot be cited as authority that a violation of §14 exists or that the specific statutory remedies described are available.
*Winchester v. O\u0019Brien*, 266 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “The plaintiff would have a right to maintain an action of trespass against the landlord for acts knowingly done, which interfere with the tenant’s comfortable enjoyment of the premises, injure his property, and cause other damage to him, even though, because of the nature of the acts or of the intention with which they are done, they do not amount to a constructive or partial eviction. … Even though the work was carried on in a reasonable and proper manner and entirely outside the rooms leased, injury was done to the property and appliances used in those rooms… and he suffered a loss of income in business.”

*Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Defendants conduct constitutes a violation of G.L. c. 186, 714, entitling Plaintiff to recover actual and consequential damages, or three months rent, whichever is greater, plus reasonable attorneys fees and court costs.
*Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The case squarely holds that a landlord’s failure to provide heat in violation of G.L. c. 186, § 14 entitles the tenant to an assessment of damages and counsel fees under that statute. While the opinion does not restate the statutory measure (actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater, plus reasonable attorney’s fees and costs), it explicitly directs the Housing Court to assess damages and award counsel fees under § 14, thereby recognizing and applying the remedial scheme referenced in the proposition.
*Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “On the facts found by the judge, the tenant was entitled on the quiet enjoyment claim to… (c) an assessment of damages and counsel fees under § 14.… The judgment is reversed and the case remanded to the Housing Court, where the tenant may move for an assessment of damages and an award of counsel fees on the quiet enjoyment claim under G. L. c. 186, § 14.”

*Dolben Co. v. Friedmann*, 2004 Mass. Ap.raw_text: *Dolben Co. v. Friedmann*, 2004 Mass. App. Div. 41 (2004)
*Dolben Co. v. Friedmann*, 2004 Mass. Ap.proposition: Defendants conduct constitutes a violation of G.L. c. 186, 714, entitling Plaintiff to recover actual and consequential damages, or three months rent, whichever is greater, plus reasonable attorneys fees and court costs.
*Dolben Co. v. Friedmann*, 2004 Mass. Ap.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns a motion to vacate a 1987 paternity and child support judgment under Mass. R. Civ. P. 60(b), focusing on adequacy of service, personal jurisdiction, and the timeliness and consideration of affidavits. It does not mention G.L. c. 186, § 14, landlord‑tenant issues, or any statutory damages, attorney’s fees, or court costs under that statute. Accordingly, it does not provide authority for the claimed proposition about a violation of G.L. c. 186, § 14 and related remedies.
*Dolben Co. v. Friedmann*, 2004 Mass. Ap.relevant_excerpt: “A judgment entered by a court which lacks personal jurisdiction over the defendant because of a lack of service of process is void from its inception… and the defendant is entitled to relief from such void judgment pursuant to M.R.C.P. 60(b)(4). … The reason is that service of process is designed to insure the defendant’s due process rights to notice and an opportunity to be heard.”

G.L. c. 239, \u001678A.proposition: This citation appears only in the complaint's "LIST OF AUTHORITIES CITED" and is not used to support any specific sentence or legal claim in the body of the complaint.
